p: In contrast to the uniform warming response, the climate response without warming of tropical Pacific SSTs yields a muted signal. The hypothetical situation of the tropical Pacific SST not warming as the rest of the globe is a technique to partition regional effects of the overall warming in different locations. Here, CA precipitation decreases by −0.27 mm day −1, not significant at the 90% confidence level. Consistently, the dynamical response is also much weaker ( Fig. 9). In fact, the east Pacific jet stream and precipitation response moves northward. Similar results ( Fig. 10) are obtained with an alternative climate model, GFDL AM3, where CA precipitation increases by 0.92 mm day −1 (significant at the 95% confidence level) in the uniform warming experiment. Without warming of tropical Pacific SSTs, CA precipitation decreases by −0.14 mm day −1, not significant at the 90% confidence level. As with CAM5, the east Pacific jet stream and precipitation response moves northward when tropical Pacific SSTs are not allowed to warm.
